terms.definition: The unavoidable duty to explain the ways in which an individual or group has carried out, or caused to be carried out, the obligations placed upon itself by law, a governing body or constitutional document.
terms.reference: Corporate governance frameworks; ISO 26000 Guidance on Social Responsibility

terms.definition: The ability of a building to be easily altered to prolong its life, for instance by alteration, addition, or contraction, to suit new uses or patterns of use.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); ISO 20887:2020

terms.definition: AECOM's policy which sets out our commitment as a company to maximise opportunities for whole life carbon reductions at all stages of the delivery process.
terms.reference: AECOM internal policy documentation

terms.definition: AECOMzero is an integrated parametric software platform compatible with industry standards, focusing on sustainable design optimization and carbon assessment throughout the project lifecycle.
terms.reference: AECOM internal tool documentation

terms.definition: Microbial breakdown of organic matter in the absence of oxygen. In a circular economy, anaerobic digestion can be used to convert food by-products, sewage sludge, and other biodegradable materials into digestates that can be used as soil enhancers and biogas.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Principal #1 of the PAS2080:2023 carbon reduction hierarchy; 'Align the outcomes of the project and/or specific design to avoid unnecessary carbon emissions and maximize value.'
terms.reference: PAS 2080:2023 Carbon Management in Infrastructure

terms.definition: The scenario for what carbon emissions and removals would have been in the absence of planned measures or interventions. Used as a reference point for measuring improvement.
terms.reference: PAS 2080:2023; Carbon management protocols; IPCC Guidelines

terms.definition: An approach to development that leaves biodiversity in a better state than before, ensuring measurable improvements to biodiversity through standardized metrics.
terms.reference: UK Environment Act 2021; Natural England BNG guidance

terms.definition: Carbon sequestered by biological processes and stored in biomaterials such as timber. This carbon can be released or remain stored depending on end-of-life treatment.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021); Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021)

terms.definition: The processes - such as composting and anaerobic digestion - that together help to regenerate natural capital. The only materials suitable for these processes are those that can be safely returned to the biosphere.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method - the world's leading sustainability assessment method for masterplanning, infrastructure and buildings.
terms.reference: BRE Global; BREEAM technical standards

terms.definition: A chemical element with symbol C. In sustainability contexts, represents greenhouse gas emissions, primarily carbon dioxide (CO2), that contribute to global warming.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); IPCC Assessment Reports

terms.definition: A policy implemented by the European Union to address climate change by placing a fair price on carbon emissions associated with imports from countries with less stringent climate policies.
terms.reference: EU CBAM Regulation 2023/956; European Commission documentation

terms.definition: Technologies that capture carbon dioxide emissions from sources like power plants and industrial facilities, then either utilize the CO2 for other purposes or store it underground to prevent atmospheric release.
terms.reference: IPCC Special Report on CCS; IEA CCUS reports

terms.definition: The release of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere as a result of human activities, primarily from burning fossil fuels.
terms.reference: IPCC Assessment Reports; Climate science literature

terms.definition: The total amount of greenhouse gases produced directly and indirectly by human activities, expressed as carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e).
terms.reference: ISO 14067:2018; Carbon Trust methodologies

terms.definition: The systematic approach to measuring, reducing, and managing greenhouse gas emissions throughout the lifecycle of projects, products, or organizational activities.
terms.reference: PAS 2080:2023; Carbon management standards

terms.definition: The use of GHG emission reductions or removals to compensate for CO2 emissions. Should only be used after maximizing direct emission reductions.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); Voluntary Carbon Market standards

terms.definition: A systems solution framework that tackles global challenges like climate change, biodiversity loss, waste, and pollution based on three principles: eliminate waste and pollution, circulate products and materials, and regenerate nature.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021), p.3

terms.definition: Actions to limit the magnitude and rate of long-term climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and enhancing carbon sinks.
terms.reference: IPCC Assessment Reports; UNFCCC documentation

terms.definition: Microbial breakdown of organic matter in the presence of oxygen. In a circular economy, composting can be used to convert food by-products and other biodegradeable materials into compost, which can be used as a soil enhancer.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Engineered wood product made from layers of lumber boards stacked in alternating directions and glued together, providing structural strength for construction.
terms.reference: Timber construction standards; CLT technical specifications

terms.definition: The process of reducing carbon dioxide emissions associated with economic activity, typically by transitioning to renewable energy sources and improving efficiency.
terms.reference: Climate policy frameworks; Decarbonisation strategies

terms.definition: Designing to support the continued use of an asset by allowing for and accommodating potential future adaptations.
Design decisions that increase the quality and quantity of materials that can be reused at the end of a building's life. Also known as design for disassembly.
terms.reference: BRE Design for Deconstruction guidance

terms.definition: The ability of a product, component or material to remain functional and relevant when used as intended. Durability often applies to the physical attributes of a product, though with some products durability can be technological or emotional.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: The GHG emissions associated with materials and construction processes throughout the whole lifecycle of an asset (Modules A1–A5, B1–B5 and C1–C4).
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); BS EN 15804

terms.definition: A third-party verified, standardised document that provides the environmental impact of a product, based on data from a life cycle assessment.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); BS EN 15804; ISO 14025

terms.definition: Materials that are non-renewable on timescales relevant to the economy, i.e. not geological timescales. Examples include: metals and minerals; fossil forms of carbon such as oil, coal, and natural gas; and sand, rocks, and stones.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Gases that trap heat in the atmosphere, including carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), and fluorinated gases.
terms.reference: IPCC Assessment Reports; Climate science literature

terms.definition: Principal #3 of the PAS2080:2023 carbon reduction hierarchy; 'Optimize the efficiency of the planned design solution to reduce carbon emissions while maximizing value.'
terms.reference: PAS 2080:2023 Carbon Management in Infrastructure

terms.definition: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design - Green building certification program that recognizes best-in-class building strategies and practices for sustainable building design and construction.
terms.reference: USGBC LEED documentation; Green building standards

terms.definition: A methodology to quantify the environmental impacts of products, services, or systems throughout their entire lifecycle from raw material extraction to end-of-life.
terms.reference: ISO 14040 series; LCA methodology standards

terms.definition: An economy in which finite resources are extracted to make products that are used - generally not to their full potential - and then thrown away ('take-make-waste'). It is a wasteful and polluting system that degrades natural systems.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Keep a product in its existing state of quality, functionally and/or cosmetically, to guard against failure or decline. It is a practice that retains the highest value of a product by extending its use period.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Achieving balance between greenhouse gases emitted and removed from the atmosphere, resulting in no net increase in atmospheric GHG concentrations.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); Net zero frameworks

terms.definition: Materials that have been previously used. This includes: materials in products that have been reused, refurbished or repaired; components that have been remanufactured; materials that have been recycled. Also referred to as secondary materials.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: The GHG emissions arising from all energy and water consumed by an asset in use, over its lifecycle (Modules B6 and B7).
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); BS EN 15804

terms.definition: British Standard specification for carbon management in infrastructure, providing framework for managing whole life carbon emissions.
terms.reference: PAS 2080:2023 Carbon Management in Infrastructure

terms.definition: The ease with which a material can be recycled in practice and at scale.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Transform a product or component into its basic materials or substances and reprocess them into new materials. Embedded energy and value are lost in the process. In a circular economy, recycling is the last resort action.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021), p.3

terms.definition: Return a product to good working order. This can include repairing or replacing components, updating specifications, and improving cosmetic appearance.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Regenerative production provides food and materials in ways that support positive outcomes for nature, which include but are not limited to: healthy and stable soils, improved local biodiversity, improved air and water quality.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Re-engineer products and components to as-new condition with the same, or improved, level of performance as a newly manufactured one. Remanufactured products or components are typically provided with a warranty that is equivalent to or better than that of the newly manufactured product.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Energy derived from resources that are not depleted on timescales relevant to the economy, i.e. not geological timescales. Examples include: wind, solar, hydropower, hydrothermal, ocean (wave and tidal), geothermal, and biogas from anaerobic digestion.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Materials that are continually replenished at a rate equal to or greater than the rate of depletion. Examples include: cotton, hemp, maize, wood, wool, leather, agricultural by-products, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and sea salt.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Operation by which a faulty or broken product or component is returned back to a usable state to fulfil its intended use.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: The repeated use of a product or component for its intended purpose without significant modification. Small adjustments and cleaning of the component or product may be necessary to prepare for the next use.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Emission reduction targets that are consistent with the pace recommended by climate scientists to limit the worst impacts of climate change.
terms.reference: Science Based Targets initiative; Climate science frameworks

terms.definition: Direct greenhouse gas emissions from sources owned or controlled by the company, such as fuel combustion in owned vehicles or facilities.
terms.reference: GHG Protocol Corporate Standard; Carbon Trust methodologies

terms.definition: Indirect emissions from the generation of purchased electricity, steam, heating and cooling consumed by the company.
terms.reference: GHG Protocol Corporate Standard; Carbon Trust methodologies

terms.definition: All other indirect emissions that occur in a company's value chain, including business travel, employee commuting, purchased goods and services, and end-of-life treatment of sold products.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); GHG Protocol Corporate Value Chain Standard

terms.definition: The removal and long-term storage of CO2 from the atmosphere in biomaterials such as timber or geological formations.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); IPCC carbon cycle documentation

terms.definition: The use of a product by multiple users. It is a practice that retains the highest value of a product by extending its use period.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: Principal #2 of the PAS2080:2023 carbon reduction hierarchy; 'Change the design to use solutions with lower carbon emissions while maximizing value.'
terms.reference: PAS 2080:2023 Carbon Management in Infrastructure

terms.definition: The processes that products and materials flow through in order to maintain their highest possible value at all times. Materials suitable for these processes are those that are not consumed during use - such as metals, plastics and wood.
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: GHG emissions up to practical completion, excluding sequestration (Modules A1–A5). Represents the carbon 'debt' that must be 'paid back' through operational savings or sequestration.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); Embodied carbon guides

terms.definition: Materials that have not yet been used in the economy. These include both finite materials (e.g. iron ore mined from the ground) and renewable resources (e.g. newly produced cotton).
terms.reference: Ellen MacArthur Foundation Circular Economy Glossary (2021)

terms.definition: The total of all GHG emissions and removals, both operational and embodied, over the lifecycle of an asset, including its disposal (Modules A–C). Potential benefits or loads from future energy recovery, reuse and recycling are reported separately (Module D).
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021); Whole life carbon guidance

terms.definition: An asset, product or service that produces no carbon emissions and therefore no offsetting is required. Also known as carbon zero, absolute zero, or gross zero.
terms.reference: Climate jargon buster, Arup (2021)
